description.plain:
alt-J is an English indie rock band that consists of vocalist and guitarist Joe Newman, keyboardist and bassist Gus Unger-Hamilton and drummer Thom Green. Gwil Sainsbury was the band’s bassist before leaving the band in early 2014.

Formed at Leeds University and signed to a label in Cambridge, UK, the band originally made songs on Garageband before releasing them under the pseudonym ∆.

∆’s name takes a little explaining. Pronounced alt-J, the delta sign is inserted when you press alt and J on a Mac keyboard.

songs.title: Breezeblocks

description.plain:
This is song from ∆’s (pronounced: Alt-J) debut album, An Awesome Wave.

“Breezeblocks” tells the story of a desperate man’s attempts to win over his love’s affections again as she has grown disillusioned, and the desperate yearning and longing that comes with love lost.

The song is inspired by the band’s love of Where The Wild Things Are by Maurice Sendak.

Newman explained to Interview Magazine:

The song is about liking someone who you want so much that you want to hurt yourself and them, as well. We related that idea to Where The Wild Things Are, which we all grew up reading, where in the end the beasts say ‘Oh, please don’t go! We’ll eat you whole! We love you so!,’ that they would threaten cannibalism to have that person – it’s a powerful image."

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rVeMiVU77wo

songs.title: Taro

description.plain:
There are so many things rolled into Taro – mournful Dispensary Girl-esque post-rock strings and bells plus vocal tone, Indian pop straddling the bridge and a history lesson.

Gerda Taro was a war photojournalist in the 1930 – 40s. She died in her line of work when a tank collided into the side of a car she was riding on.

The subject of this song is Gerda’s romantic interest and colleague, Robert Capa. During the First Indochina War, Capa left the relative safety of his Jeep and advanced on foot in a hostile war zone to take pictures. Minutes later, he stepped on a landmine, which blew apart his left leg. He died minutes later with his camera in his hand.

songs.title: In Cold Blood

description.plain:
In Cold Blood is the second single off of Alt-J’s third full length LP, “Relaxer”. It premiered on March 29th, 2017 live on Mistajam’s show on BBC Radio One. The band introduced this song in their newsletter and on social media saying:

It’s a song we began writing in our Leeds days and finished last year in London. The brass was recorded at Abbey Road; the keyboards were done on a Casiotone that cost £1.05 on eBay; and no-one is quite sure where the key change came from. We hope you enjoy it.

The band announced the song on Instagram and Facebook.

The song seems to be describing a fun, wild, careless pool party gone wrong, and could be commentary on how society tends to view summer as only a time of pleasantry, whereas the reality of it can be quite harsh.

In an interview with BBC Radio 6 Gus Unger-Hamilton said that the lyrics were “not massively deep” and that people on the internet had interpretations much deeper than anything they had.

songs.title: Fitzpleasure

description.plain:
“Fitzpleasure,” the album’s most frenetic and even schizophrenic composition, jumps between Gregorian chant to Afropop-tinged dubstep to ethereal electronica yet never feels contrived. Lyrically, it’s nearly indecipherable, obscured by Joe Newman’s nasal falsetto vocals that recall tribal singers from nearly any continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

In an interview, Joe Newman explained that the song is based on Hubert Selby Jr.’s 1964 novel Last Exit to Brooklyn. It was later adapted into a 1989 British/German film directed by Uli Edel.

songs.title: Left Hand Free

description.plain:
The second single off of This Is All Yours is described by the band members as the “least Alt-J song ever”. It was rumoured to have been made in large part to appease the label, who wanted them to make a “big single” – something they didn’t believe was true of the first single “Hunger of the Pine”.

In the Guardian article, each member had their own take on the song:


I tried to make the drums as clichéd as possible, there’s none of my personality in it. — Thom

I’m doing some kind of organ solo. I don’t know where ‘baby’ came from. — Gus

And I say, ‘Gee whiz,’ which I’m not sure is a phrase I’ve ever uttered before. I can imagine it appealing to American truckers with Good Riddance To Bin Laden stickers! — Joe

Oh God… Someone’s going to walk onstage to it at an NRA convention. — Gus


Later, however, the band denied that they were forced to write the song. Take Thom Green’s response to a fan’s question and alt-J’s tweet:

https://twitter.com/alt_J/status/486632253154263040

In an interview, keyboard player Gus Unger-Hamilton stated that the things said by the Guardian were misunderstood, and the song wasn’t written for the label:

No, no, no, no, no, no, no, it was something we came up with spontaneously. It was the product of having fun one afternoon in the writers’ studio and enjoying ourselves. We found out once we laid down the track that the American label, that was the song they responded best to. But it was definitely not written in any way for the label, to please the label or to piss the label off, or whatever people have been saying. No.

songs.title: Tessellate

description.plain:
In which the ultimate Shorty Said soundalikes roll on with Tessellate, the most Devendra Banhart of all Alt-J songs. Doesn’t matter though, because its piano lollop is as pleasingly creepy as all their other stuff, helped by the superbly delivered line,

And all your friends come…

A pleasingly creepy slice of brilliance.

Drummer Thom Green on the song:

We wrote the song in Leeds and it started when I was trying to emulate a Deftones style drum beat actually. We always knew where the track was going to go but our producer helped us strip things away and create a lot more space – it’s almost got a hip-hop feel to it in places.

When asked about the meaning of the track in an interview with NME, frontman Joe Newman also said:

I wrote it when I was going out with my ex-girlfriend. I started going out with someone else and the song’s about getting over her while I was going out with my new girlfriend.

  


Ellie Goulding has done an incredible cover herself. Check it out.

http://youtu.be/geSScmBWBtE

songs.title: Matilda

description.plain:
Named after Natalie Portman’s character in Leon: The Professional, the name of the song follows the English spelling rather than the French spelling of “Mathilda” used in the film. “Matilda"’s drab strum is a paean to Luc Besson’s troubled child-star in his 1994 film Leon: The Professional – it’s all the better for the added grit, real-life misery and heartache.

Before their debut album, they released another song, titled “Leon,” that was inspired by the film.

Note: This song’s annotations contain spoilers for the aforementioned film. Only the first is marked.

songs.title: Hunger of the Pine

description.plain:
“Hunger of the Pine” is the first single from their 2014 album, This Is All Yours.

Keyboardist Gus Unger-Hamilton had this to say on the songwriting process after the departure of former bassist Gwil Sainsbury (via NPR):


Having to write songs as a trio rather than a foursome was a daunting prospect for us at first, but coming up with this song reassured us that — for want of a better phrase — we were going to be OK.

[It is] composed entirely of new and spontaneous ideas that arose during writing sessions for the second album. It was written very quickly using some guitar chords and sounds being layered on Ableton, and seemed to signal a bit of a new sound for us. The lyrics mainly suggest the idea that missing someone — pining — can be a physical pain much like hunger.

songs.title: 3WW

description.plain:
3WW is the first single, and opening track, off of Alt-J’s third full length LP, Relaxer. The title ‘3WW’ stands for “3 worn words”. This song’s teaser uses imagery and scenery taken from the Japanese PlayStation 1 game known as “LSD: Dream Emulator”. In a newsletter to fans the band said that the song “traces the adventures of a wayward lad on England’s northeast coast, culminating in the whispering of three worn words. Let’s not beat around the bush – we think it could be the best thing we’ve done to date.”

The official music video for the song was directed by Young Replicant and was filmed in Real De Catorce, Mexico.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwBkXgWNs_M

This song’s release was also themed after the number 3. The teaser for the song was released on 3/3, the full song was released 3 days later, and the album was originally set to release 3 months and 3 days later. The song also features 3 singers (Joe Newman, Gus Unger-Hamilton and Ellie Rowsell) singing as 3 different characters. The “3” motif also fits the three sides of the band’s triangle symbol.

songs.title: Deadcrush

description.plain:
“Deadcrush” is about two long-deceased historical women who members of ∆ (Alt-J) have crushes on. The “DC” in the chorus is an abbreviation for what alt-J have dubbed this
phenomenon: a"deadcrush". The song premiered on BBC Radio 6 on May 31st, 2017.

The video for the song was directed by Young Replicant and imagines the band’s three deadcrushes (Lee Miller, Anne Boleyn and Sylvia Plath) being brought to life by an advanced computer in a post-apocalyptic world. The band elaborated on the video’s concept & creation extensively when they premiered it on WeTransfer. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GOJUNJ1o394

songs.title: Nara

description.plain:
The third track on This Is All Yours, Nara is the second song in the three-part named after the Japanese city. The song is about a gay man wanting to marry. It was written around the time of the Russian Winter Olympics in the beginning of 2014.

The song is sprinkled with allusions to other works, from songs (“Petrol Blues” by The Rolling Stones) to books (C. S. Lewis) and films (Blue Is The Warmest Colour), and even photography.

The song is featured in the 2015 video game, “Life Is Strange”, during the start of Episode 2, when Max is getting up.

songs.title: Bloodflood

description.plain:
Bloodflood, about being flooded with fear, is the source for the name of the album (An Awesome Wave). This lyric is an embodiment of the record, evoking the concept of being engulfed by events and emotions. Alt-J almost go out of their way to be obscure in the lyrics, but eventually the melodies – and the meanings – emerge.

It’s about the feeling you get when faced with dread, like you’re about to get punched, or you’ve realised you’ve left your fucking passport in the hotel.

- Thom Green

Bloodflood Pt. II appears on the album This Is All Yours.

songs.title: ❦ (Ripe & Ruin)

description.plain:
❦

This song is also known as “Interlude 1” or “Interlude I”.

The fleuron character or “printer’s flower” (❦) used in the title of this song is used in book printing to divide paragraphs – or in the case of this song, an interlude to divide the album into segments. Use of a non-alphanumeric character is reminiscent of the band’s name itself, a Greek delta symbol (Δ) pronounced as “alt-J” because of the keyboard combination needed to type it on an Apple keyboard.

The song seems to present us with a woman caught in a schedule and living day-by-day, hoping and praying for the best, but failing to grasp the ‘fruit’ of life whilst she’s young enough to do so.

songs.full_title: The Gospel of John Hurt by ​​alt-J
songs.title: The Gospel of John Hurt

description.plain:
Warning: annotations contain spoilers for the film Alien, and content that some readers may find disturbing (graphic violence, gore)

Like “Matilda”, “The Gospel of John Hurt” was inspired by a film – in this case, Alien, one of Hurt’s best-known roles.



It’s particularly inspired by Hurt’s death scene, where an alien bursts out of his chest. This shocking scene was a surprise even to Hurt’s fellow actors, who didn’t know just how gory it was going to be. Today, it stands as one of the most iconic scenes in sci-fi and horror films.

Speaking via The Guardian in 2014, Joe Newman said this about the track:

That scene has stayed with me. As a writer, you’re meant to sift through all of things you’ve remembered in your life and pinpoint the things you’ve been moved by. Why not write about those moments you’re moved by the most?

“Dissolve Me” betrays a jazz influence in the way it meanders in a manner that most indie bands cannot manage.

The name “dissolve me” may be a reference to drug use, but also a continuation of the theme on the album of a love that’s passionate, unpredictable, and at times dream- or trance-like.

songs.title: Pusher

description.plain:
“Pusher” is a stripped-down acoustic number about love, loss and loneliness. Its central idea is that people are either pushers or pullers, and a successful relationship needs both – Newman sings of how he lacks

the zest of a lemon, looking forward
Unless I have a woman pushing me

It also introduces the red-billed quelea, the most common bird in the world, which will reoccur throughout the album.

songs.full_title: House of the Rising Sun by ​​alt-J
songs.title: House of the Rising Sun

description.plain: The May 2017 issue of Q Magazine described this song as a cover and mentioned that it features contributions from twenty classical guitarists. Before the song became available alt-J hid a YouTube link to The Animals' well-known version of the folk song in their website’s exploration game but in an interview with Philadelphia’s Radio 104.5 keyboardist Gus Unger-Hamilton described the song as “not a cover of The Animals” but rather “sort of our version of the folk song”. In a later interview, he added that the second verse and chorus of their version are original and that “it’s an original piece of work and not just chucking in a cover to fill space as it were”.

songs.title: Last Year

description.plain: A tranquil song in two parts that tells the story of the narrator’s “Last Year”, which was both the year before this one and and also the last year of his life. The first part is a narrator recounting the months the led to his ultimate suicide in December. The second part is the song that his former partner “sang at [his] funeral”.

songs.title: Pleader

description.plain:
alt-J previewed this song for Q Magazine’s May 2017 issue, which described it as being inspired by the novel How Green Was My Valley.  The song was partly recorded in Ely Cathedral where keyboardist/backup vocalist Gus Unger-Hamilton used to be a chorister.



  In a later interview keyboardist Gus Unger-Hamilton described the song as “ almost a secular piece of religious music” and singer/guitarist Joe Newman explained that for the lyrics he collected a lot of visuals from the novel and “filtered through an alt-J world”.

The quiet section at the beginning is a recording of the ambience of Ely Cathedral. In it you can hear the sound of of the old Victorian heaters there, someone walking, and a voice, presumably a chorister warming up.

songs.title: Hand-Made

description.plain: One of the many possible interpretations is that this song could be about is a drug addiction: In the beginning of the song (or rather the chorus) he talks about his body going numb and scratching himself until he bleeds, a very common way to describe drug usage. Then the therapist asks if he is ready to begin talking. In Verse 1, he describes his paranoia, a common side effect of any drug, and his want to not leave his house, as the drugs hold him tight. I believe the object changes when he says I’m absorbed in your thinking, this may be his own thinking (through perhaps an alter-ego). He is either trying to get clean for a love of his, or more likely for himself.

songs.title: U&ME

description.plain:
“U&ME” tells a euphoric love story that devolves into a drug trip but nevertheless remains a cherished memory. The song arrived with the announcement of the band’s fourth LP, The Dream.

According to the alt-J newsletter to fans…

“It was the first track we worked on and recorded for our new album The Dream, and so it felt right to be the one we share with you first. It’s quite simply a song about good times in the summer sun – too good perhaps. In the video we’ve taken this idea and translated it to the skate park – @prosper99999 documented the day that we sold our souls to reach frightening new heights of skill on the ramps and in the bowls…”

The video shows the trio having a ball at the skate park, with things getting a little weird because it wouldn’t be an alt-J video otherwise.

What is unique about this video is that it is the first in which the band members have taken the lead role, with only one small cameo in their previous releases.

songs.title: ❦ (Garden of England)

description.plain:
This interlude features sounds of birds, nature, and cheerful sounding recorders.

The fleuron character (❦) in the title is the same that they used for the “❦ (Ripe & Ruin)” interlude on their previous album, An Awesome Wave. The flower is most likely included in the title due to the fact that plants are often grown in a “garden.”

The title may be an allusion to the biblical Garden of Eden, given its similar wording. However, the “Garden Of England” is the nickname of Kent, the most south-eastern county of Britain.

songs.title: Buffalo

description.plain:
Written for the soundtrack of Silver Linings Playbook and featuring Mountain Man (best known for backing Feist), “Buffalo” is a beautiful track that many agree showcases all of the versatility and talent that make so much of Alt-J’s music an instant classic.

As Spin magazine puts it:

The intricately gloaming track neatly demonstrates the hybrid of rootsy folk and future-bent electronics that helped the band’s September debut An Awesome Wave nab Britain’s Mercury Prize.

songs.title: Hard Drive Gold

description.plain:
“Hard Drive Gold” is a teenager’s juvenile fantasy of becoming an overnight millionaire by trading cryptocurrency. alt-J describe the song as “tongue-in-cheek”.

The track dropped as the third single leading up to the release of The Dream. In keeping with the band’s tradition of using music videos to create and showcase short films instead of replicating tired “indie band music video tropes”. This time, however, instead of giving the project to a director, lead singer Joe Newman directed the video with his partner, who previously choreographed the band’s video for “Deadcrush”. The short tells the story of an athelete who, with the help of her late mother, uses her last four minutes alive to nail a pole vault jump.

songs.title: Portrait

description.plain: ‘Portrait’ was recorded under the FILMS moniker, and is the earliest [pre] alt-J recording out there. The track has a far greater rock influence, but it just isn’t in the same league as any of the tracks on An Awesome Wave. Alt-J were later forced to drop the name FILMS due to copyright issues with an American punk band of the same name.

songs.full_title: Pleader (Trooko Version) by ​​alt-J (Ft. PJ Sin Suela)
songs.title: Pleader (Trooko Version)

description.plain:
It was a pleasure to work on this remix. After doing my research and finding out that the inspiration of the song is based on a book called “How Green Was My Valley” everything made sense. My hometown, Puerto Rico, has been in an economic crisis for sometime now and things got worse after Hurricane María hit. I’ve seen many friends have to leave Puerto Rico or ?my green valley? in order to survive, find jobs and better opportunities. The song is a portrait of a person or of people who have to leave there “PATRIA” or the land they love but always have it in their heart and are waiting for the opportunity to go back and make it a better place.
_
Fun fact: I found the official original video of Pleader after we did the song, it was good to know everything made sense.
_
“After everyone Huw, the main character of the book, has known either dies or moves away, and the town is reduced to a contaminated shell, he decides to leave, and tells the story of his life just before going away.”

songs.title: The Actor

description.plain:
Description of alt-J’s song release e-mail:
“Hollywood, 1982. Another hopeful young movie star arrives in search of The Dream. What follows is a tale of desperation, drugs and death in LA’s most famous hotel.”

The song feels like an abstract image of an unexperienced actor wanting to realise his dream of an acting career in LA. He’s facing the brutal business of hollywood especially in the famous Chateau Marmont Hotel where desperation, drugs and death are everyday stuff.

He’s trying but doesn’t succeed. To cope with his feelings he’s  […] “returning to you” […], cocaine.

songs.full_title: Last Year (Terrace Martin Version) by ​​alt-J (Ft. GoldLink)
songs.title: Last Year (Terrace Martin Version)

description.plain:
Last Year might not seem like well-suited for a hip-hop remix with its slow, drained whisper and melancholy subject, but Terrace Martin and GoldLink found a way to make it work. GoldLink’s verse includes themes of love and death similar to the original version of the song. alt-J included thoughts from the two artists while releasing the video on social media. Terrace Martin said:

“This record is special to me because it truly reflects freedom and what it means to have no boundaries. I actually produced this record in Poland fuelled by nothing but a cup full of espresso.”

GoldLink had the following to say:

“Alt-J and Terrace Martin are two artists I respect immensely, so I was honoured to tell a story with them on this new album of RELAXER remixes.”

The video for the song was made by Jay Kzapa, adding a gorgeously-animated sort of fairytale story featuring love, loss, rebirth and redemption.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gOwlY9ITazA

songs.title: A Real Hero

description.plain:
A cover of College and Electric Youth’s A Real Hero, recorded in 2013 in Toronto for their iTunes exclusive album.

The song is about pilot Chesley ‘Sully’ Sullenburger, who successfully emergency-landed in airplane on New York’s Hudson River in 2009. The original song by College was featured in 2011 movie Drive.

songs.title: Taro (French Version)

description.plain:
Cette chanson provient de “An Awesome Wave”, le premier album d'Alt-J qui a révélé le groupe.

Elle parle de la mort du photographe de guerre Robert Capa et de son amour pour sa compagne Gerda Taro, elle aussi photographe de guerre, morte 17 ans auparavant.

Elle utilise des sonorités post-rock ainsi que des cloches et des sons inspirés de la pop indienne durant le pont.

songs.embed_content: Read “Taro (French Version)” by ​​alt-J on Genius

body.plain:
Cette chanson provient de “An Awesome Wave”, le premier album d'Alt-J qui a révélé le groupe.

Elle parle de la mort du photographe de guerre Robert Capa et de son amour pour sa compagne Gerda Taro, elle aussi photographe de guerre, morte 17 ans auparavant.

Elle utilise des sonorités post-rock ainsi que des cloches et des sons inspirés de la pop indienne durant le pont.

songs.lyrics:
Taro (French Version) Lyrics
Indochina
Capa jumps Jeep, two feet creep up the road
To photo, to record, meat lumps and war
They advance as does his chance
Very yellow white flash!
A violent wrench grips mass, rips light, tears limbs like rags
Burst so high finally Capa lands
Mine is a watery pit
Painless with immense distance
From medic from colleague, friend, enemy, foe, him five yards from his leg
From you
Taro
Do not spray into eyes – I have sprayed you into my eyes


3:10 pm
Capa pends death, quivers, last rattles, last chokes
All colours and cares glaze to grey
Shriveled and stricken to dots
The left hand grasps what the body grasps not le photographe est mort
3.1415, alive no longer my amour
Faded for home May of ‘54
Doors open like arms, my love
Painless with a great closeness
To Capa, to Capa Capa dark after nothing, re-united with his leg and with you
Taro
Do not spray into eyes – I have sprayed you into my eyes
(Hey Taro!)2Embed
